Omorgus loxus
is similar in appearance to
O. badeni
and
O. borrei
. These three species may be separated by the differences on the elytra.
Omorgus loxus
have distinct pilose tubercles, whereas
O. borrei
have glabrous black tubercles and
O. badeni
have black lustrous patches. Furthermore,
O. loxus
have the outer margin of the mesotibiae smooth, whereas the other two species have it serrate. For a more detailed treatment of the species, see Vaurie (1962) and Scholtz (1990).

Omorgus loxus
occurs in southeastern Mexico , Central America and parts of South America (French Guiana, Colombia , Argentina , Brazil and Paraguay ). It is thought to have a continuous distribution throughout its range. In Brazil , it has recorded in the Cerrado (GO, MG, MS and TO) and Atlantic Forest (ES, SC, SP) biomes ( Figure 9 ). For a more detailed discussion on the distribution of this species see Vaurie (1955 , 1962 )), Scholtz (1990) and Hielkema and Hielkema (2019) .
